lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters and adjectives mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before the story, say: “Listen for these words: big, small, long.” Students raise hands when they hear them.
stretchStrategies: Role-Play with a Twist – After reading the story, assign characters and challenge students to retell or extend the story using one new adjective in every sentence they say (e.g., “It’s a small boat!” “That’s a big fish!”). Encourage acting and exaggeration to embed adjectives naturally into speech.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud. Students echo each sentence. Assign simple roles and act out with gestures.
stretchStrategies: Role-Play with a Twist – After reading the story, assign characters and challenge students to retell or extend the story using one new adjective in every sentence they say (e.g., “It’s a small boat!” “That’s a big fish!”). Encourage acting and exaggeration to embed adjectives naturally into speech.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Pause the story at the end. Ask: “What could happen next?” Students draw or mime the next part.
stretchStrategies: Role-Play with a Twist – After reading the story, assign characters and challenge students to retell or extend the story using one new adjective in every sentence they say (e.g., “It’s a small boat!” “That’s a big fish!”). Encourage acting and exaggeration to embed adjectives naturally into speech.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
